STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 5, 2024
Laura Nye
Hillsdale DHHS
40 Care Drive,
Hillsdale, MI, 49242-5039
RE: License#: CP300201172
Dear Ms. Nye:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 2/28/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP300201172
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Laura Nye
Name of Agency: Hillsdale County DHHS
Agency Address: 40 Care Drive
Hillsdale, MI 49242-5039
Agency Telephone #: (517) 439-2200
Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1992
Service Types: Place children for adoption, certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
One of eight foster care files did not have the documentation required for a
change of placement. This documentation was missing for two moves for one
child.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically
indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required
by section 5111 of the public health code, 1978
PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy
of the waiver is unavailable, then immunizations
must begin within 30 calendar days of
placement.

(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at
least every 9 months, unless a greater
frequency is indicated.
(c,ii) One of eight foster care files did not have a physical exam completed within
the required timeframe.
(d) One of eight foster care files had overdue immunizations and did not have
documentation of a plan to bring them current.
(f) Two of eight foster care files did not have dental exams completed every nine
months.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from
the medical or dental provider of all medical and dental
care received by a foster child.
One of eight foster care files did not have documentation for a dental exam.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement
or replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the
foster parent to provide a stable, safe, and
healthy environment for the foster child and the
foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home as
provided in federal law.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and
emergency medical care.

One of eight foster care files did not have documentation the required information
was provided to a foster parent at placement.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents.
Two of eight foster care files held treatment plans that were not signed by a
parent to indicate participation in the plan and a receipt of a copy.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
Two of eight foster care files were each missing one monthly home visit with the
youth.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Two of eight foster care files did not have an 1105 report completed to
accompany an FTM.

FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
(Page 1) For children entering foster care, the initial
medical passport must be provided within two weeks of
the child's placement date to the following: • Foster
care provider.
(Page 2) All medical information within the medical
passport must be current and updated at least quarterly
to reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
(Page 1) Four of eight foster care files did not have documentation that a Medical
Passport was provided to the foster parent within two weeks of placement.
(Page 2) Two of eight foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical
passports completed.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Interviews with all household members must be detailed in the special
evaluation report. Specifically interviews with children when the allegation is
regarding physical discipline.
• When youth age out of foster care, the DHHS-69 form should document the
items provided to the youth, such as their birth certificate and social security
card. This is DHHS policy, not a licensing rule, but it is best practice.
• Reporting sources to Children's Services must not be identified in case
contacts in a USP. Hidden text boxes in MiSACWIS may be used for
information that should not print to the USP/PATP.
• MiSACWIS users must follow the online guide to upload documents to the
proper location.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
A CAP, approved 5/3/23, was the result of the 4/27/23 Interim review. The agency
addressed violations regarding special evaluations and independent living. During
the current review, it was determined the CAP was implemented successfully, as
there are no repeat violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed on-site. The
Chief Administrator (CA) reported success with the 2023 CAP, and no further
concerns in those areas. The CA reported new processes were developed
regarding special evaluations and independent living. Both of which seem to have
corrected the prior issue. The CA identified some disrupted/unplanned moves
during the past year, due to significant behavioral concerns of youth.
Hospitalization was required in many of those incidents. Other unplanned moves
were the result of youth committing a crime or violating probation, which resulted
in placement in detention or residential. The CA reported the overall lack of
available foster homes has made it difficult to secure placements. The agency
continues to develop strategies to overcome barriers to licensure.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed, one licensing worker and one foster care worker. Both
staff reported they enjoy their positions and feel supported by their supervisor and
administration. Neither staff had any concerns nor identified areas for
improvement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same county building as previous
years. The office provides secure storage for confidential information, and
adequate space for staff and clients.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL analyst identified two safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert 1: On 10/13/23 an unlicensed relative caregiver had a wood burning
pellet stove in the kitchen without any safety guards to protect the 18mo toddler.
Resolution: Agency staff met to discuss the findings. The licensing worker
contacted the caregiver and identified the solution to place a gate around the wood
stove. The caregiver agreed to always supervise the child near the stove. A photo of
the installed gate was provided to the agency on 10/20/23 and verified during a visit
on 10/23/23.
Safety Alert 2: On 10/30/23 it was determined the home needed a CO2 detector.
Resolution: On 10/31/12 the caregiver provided the agency with a video of the
installed CO2 detector. The child’s adoption worker visited the home on 11/3/23 and
verified the CO2 detector was installed and working.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_ _________February 29, 2024________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 5, 2024
